query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 La gloria di colui che tutto move 2 per l’universo penetra, e risplende 3 in una parte più e meno altrove.
query.result:
**English:**
1 The glory of Him who moves all things 2 penetrates through the universe, and shines 3 more in one part and less in another.
**Old English:**
1 Þæs wuldres Wealdend, se ðe geworhte 2 þurh ðæs mihtigan Meotudes meaht 3 on ðam rodores ryneð and ræseð, 4 and ðisne middangeard monigfealde 5 geworhte wundrumlufu wuldres Fæder, 6 eallmehtig God, ðurh ðæs gæstes cræft, 7 ðurh ðæs hehstan Hæleðes higeþancas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Veramente quant’ io del regno santo 11 ne la mia mente potei far tesoro, 12 sarà ora materia del mio canto.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Truly, as much as I could treasure in my mind 11 of the holy realm, 12 will now be the subject of my song.
**Old English:**
10 Soðlice ðæt ðe ic ðæs halgan rices 11 on ðam mode minum gemunan mihte, 12 ðæt bið nu ðære lare ðæs leoðes mæst.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 O buono Appollo, a l’ultimo lavoro 14 fammi del tuo valor sì fatto vaso, 15 come dimandi a dar l’amato alloro.
query.result:
**English:**
13 O good Apollo, for this final labor 14 make me a vessel worthy of your power, 15 as you require in order to grant the beloved laurel.
**Old English:**
13 O god Apollō, to ðis endebyrde 14 wyrc ðæt ic sie ðinre mihte ðæs fætes, 15 swa ðu bebeodest ðæt ðu ðone leofan laur sele.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Infino a qui l’un giogo di Parnaso 17 assai mi fu; ma or con amendue 18 m’è uopo intrar ne l’aringo rimaso.
query.result:
**English:**
16 Up to this point, one peak of Parnassus 17 was enough for me; but now with both 18 I must enter the remaining lists.
**Old English:**
16 Oð ðisne sið Parnassus mōntes 17 wæs mē genōg; ac nū mid twǣm 18 mē is neod ðæt ic on ðone wægræd fare.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Entra nel petto mio, e spira tue 20 sì come quando Marsïa traesti 21 de la vagina de le membra sue.

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 O divina virtù, se mi ti presti 23 tanto che l’ombra del beato regno 24 segnata nel mio capo io manifesti,
25 vedra’mi al piè del tuo diletto legno 26 venire, e coronarmi de le foglie 27 che la materia e tu mi farai degno.
query.result:
**English:**
22 O divine virtue, if you grant me 23 so much that I may reveal the shadow of the blessed realm 24 imprinted in my mind,
25 you will see me come to the foot of your beloved tree 26 and crown myself with the leaves 27 that both matter and you will make me worthy of.
**Old English:**
22 Eala, godcunde miht, gif ðu ðe me geunne, 23 ðæt ic ðæs eadigan rices sceadu, 24 ðe on minum mode gemearcod is, mæge cyðan,
25 ðonne gesyhð ðu ðæt ic to ðinum leofan treowe 26 cume and me sylfne mid ðam leafum bewreode, 27 ðe ðu and ðeos gesceaft me wyrðe geworhte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Sì rade volte, padre, se ne coglie 29 per trïunfare o cesare o poeta, 30 colpa e vergogna de l’umane voglie,
31 che parturir letizia in su la lieta 32 delfica deïtà dovria la fronda 33 peneia, quando alcun di sé asseta.
query.result:
**English:**
28 So rarely, father, is it gathered 29 for a triumph, whether of Caesar or of poet, 30 the fault and shame of human desires,
31 that the Peneian laurel, when someone is crowned with it, 32 ought to make glad the joyful 33 Delphic deity.
**Old English:**
28 Swa seldcum, fæder, hit gelimpeð 29 ðurh sige oððe searocræft, 30 syn and scamu manna geþohtes,
31 ðæt ðæs leoman leoðu belimpe 32 ðære bliðan Delfican gyððe, 33 ðonne he ænigne him to setle geceoseð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Poca favilla gran fiamma seconda: 35 forse di retro a me con miglior voci 36 si pregherà perché Cirra risponda.
query.result:
**English:**
34 A small spark can start a great flame: 35 perhaps behind me, with better voices, 36 someone will pray so that Cirra will answer.
**Old English:**
34 Lytel fyr micel fyr mæg æfter cuman: 35 mæg ðonne eft byreð betere stemne 36 ðæt ðurh Cirran gehyreð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Surge ai mortali per diverse foci 38 la lucerna del mondo; ma da quella 39 che quattro cerchi giugne con tre croci,
40 con miglior corso e con migliore stella 41 esce congiunta, e la mondana cera 42 più a suo modo tempera e suggella.
query.result:
**English:**
37 To mortals arises from diverse regions 38 the lamp of the world; but from that one 39 which joins four circles with three crosses,
40 with a better course and with a better star 41 it comes forth conjoined, and the worldly wax 42 it tempers and seals more to its liking.
**Old English:**
37 Arisð to ðæm deadlicum ðurh mislice stowe 38 ðæs middangeardes leoht; ac of ðæm anum 39 ðe feower hringas gegaderað mid ðrim rodortacenum,
40 mid beteran ræse and mid beteran steorran 41 hit cymeð gegaderod, and ðæs middangeardes wax 42 hit gemetgað and gemyrðð mara æfter his willan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Fatto avea di là mane e di qua sera 44 tal foce, e quasi tutto era là bianco 45 quello emisperio, e l’altra parte nera,
46 quando Beatrice in sul sinistro fianco 47 vidi rivolta e riguardar nel sole: 48 aguglia sì non li s’affisse unquanco.
query.result:
**English:**
43 It had made morning there and evening here, 44 such a horizon, and almost all of that hemisphere was white, 45 and the other part black,
46 when Beatrice on my left side 47 I saw turned and gazing at the sun: 48 never did an eagle fix its gaze on it so intently.
**Old English:**
43 Hæfde geworht ðær dæges and nihtes 44 swylce ende, and neah eall wæs ðær hwit 45 ðæt healfe heofones, and ðæt oðer swart,
46 ða ic Beatrice on ðone wynstran healf 47 geseah bewende and on ða sunnan wlitan: 48 næfre earn swa stiðe ne geseah.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 E sì come secondo raggio suole 50 uscir del primo e risalire in suso, 51 pur come pelegrin che tornar vuole,
52 così de l’atto suo, per li occhi infuso 53 ne l’imagine mia, il mio si fece, 54 e fissi li occhi al sole oltre nostr’ uso.
query.result:
**English:**
49 And just as a second ray is wont 50 to issue from the first and rise upward, 51 just like a pilgrim who wants to return,
52 so from his action, infused through the eyes 53 into my image, mine was made, 54 and I fixed my eyes on the sun beyond our custom.
**Old English:**
49 And swa swa æfterra beam bið gewuna 50 of ðam forman cuman and up astigan, 51 swa swa ðone wegfarend ðe eft gewendan wile,
52 swa of his weorce ðurh ða eagan agoten 53 on ðære minre anlicnesse min geworhte, 54 and ic fæste ða eagan to ðære sunnan ofer ure gewunan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Molto è licito là, che qui non lece 56 a le nostre virtù, mercé del loco 57 fatto per proprio de l’umana spece.
query.result:
**English:**
55 Much is permitted there that here is not permitted 56 to our virtues, thanks to the place 57 made specifically for the human race.
**Old English:**
55 Micel is ðær geðafod ðæt her nis alyfed 56 urum mægenum, ðurh ðæs stowes gecynd 57 ðe geworht wæs ðurh ðæs mannes gecynd.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Beatrice tutta ne l’etterne rote 65 fissa con li occhi stava; e io in lei 66 le luci fissi, di là sù rimote.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Beatrice, all in the crimson garment, 65 stood with her eyes fixed; and I on her, 66 my gaze fixed, from up there afar.
**Old English:**
64 Beatriðe eall on ðære readan gyrelan 65 fæste mid ðam eagum stod; and ic on hyre 66 ða leohtu fæste, of ðonon ufeor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Nel suo aspetto tal dentro mi fei, 68 qual si fé Glauco nel gustar de l’erba 69 che ’l fé consorto in mar de li altri dèi.
query.result:
**English:**
67 At his appearance I made myself such within, 68 as Glaucus became when he tasted the herb 69 that made him a sea-god among the other gods.
**Old English:**
67 On his ansyn ða ic me innan geworhte, 68 swa swa Glaucus dyde ða he ðæt gærs gebæd, 69 ðæt hine on sælicne god geworhte mid ðam oðrum godum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Trasumanar significar per verba 71 non si poria; però l’essemplo basti 72 a cui esperïenza grazia serba.
query.result:
**English:**
70 To signify transcendence through words 71 would not be possible; therefore, let the example suffice 72 for one to whom grace grants experience.
**Old English:**
70 Ufan stigan bi wordum secgan 71 nis ðæt mæge; forðæm ðæt andgit genihtsum 72 ðæm ðe ðurh ðæs gastes gife gifeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 S’i’ era sol di me quel che creasti 74 novellamente, amor che ’l ciel governi, 75 tu ’l sai, che col tuo lume mi levasti.
query.result:
**English:**
73 If I was alone of myself that which You created 74 anew, O Love that governs the heavens, 75 You know it, who with Your light lifted me up.
**Old English:**
73 Gif ic wæs ana min self ðæt ðu gesceope 74 niwelice, lufu ðe ðone heofon reced, 75 ðu ðæt wast, ðe mid ðinum leohte me up ahef.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Quando la rota che tu sempiterni 77 desiderato, a sé mi fece atteso 78 con l’armonia che temperi e discerni,
79 parvemi tanto allor del cielo acceso 80 de la fiamma del sol, che pioggia o fiume 81 lago non fece alcun tanto disteso.
query.result:
**English:**
76 When the wheel that you make eternal 77 and desired, drew me to itself 78 with the harmony that you moderate and discern,
79 then it seemed to me that so much of heaven was kindled 80 by the flame of the sun that no rain or river 81 or lake ever made so vast an expanse.
**Old English:**
76 Þonne ðæt hweol ðe ðu symle ece 77 gewilnode, to ðe mec gefette 78 mid ðære stemne ðe ðu tempre and todælst,
79 ða ðuhte me swa micel of heofenum 80 ongunnen fram ðære sunnan lige, 81 ðæt næfre regn ne flod ne mere 82 swa micelne rum ne geworhte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 La novità del suono e ’l grande lume 83 di lor cagion m’accesero un disio 84 mai non sentito di cotanto acume.
query.result:
**English:**
82 The novelty of the sound and the great light 83 of them aroused in me a desire 84 never felt before with such intensity.
**Old English:**
82 Þæs swēges niwlicnes and þæs leohta mickle 83 hyra gesceafta onwæcnedon on mē gewilnunge 84 næfre ær gehyrdre mid swylcum andan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Ond’ ella, che vedea me sì com’ io, 86 a quïetarmi l’animo commosso, 87 pria ch’io a dimandar, la bocca aprio
88 e cominciò: «Tu stesso ti fai grosso 89 col falso imaginar, sì che non vedi 90 ciò che vedresti se l’avessi scosso.
query.result:
**English:**
85 And she, who saw me as I was, 86 to calm my troubled soul, 87 before I asked, opened her mouth
88 and began: "You yourself make yourself gross 89 with false imagining, so that you do not see 90 what you would see if you had shaken it off.
**Old English:**
85 And heo ðe me geseah swa swa ic wæs, 86 ða heo ðone mod ðone gedrefedan gestilde, 87 ær ðam ðe ic ða spræce ongunne, ða heo ðone muð ontýnde
88 and ðus ða wordum cwæð: "Ðu ðe selfne ðone miclan wyrcst 89 ðurh ðone leasan ðancol, ðæt ðu ne gesihst 90 ðæt ðu gesawe gif ðu ðone of ðe asceoce."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Tu non se’ in terra, sì come tu credi; 92 ma folgore, fuggendo il proprio sito, 93 non corse come tu ch’ad esso riedi».
query.result:
**English:**
91 You are not on earth, as you believe; 92 but lightning, fleeing its proper place, 93 did not speed as you do, returning to it.
**Old English:**
91 ðu nart on eorðan, swa ðu wēnst; 92 ac ðunorlēg, fleonde his āgenne stede, 93 ne fleah swa ðu ðe ðær eft cyrrest».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 S’io fui del primo dubbio disvestito 95 per le sorrise parolette brevi, 96 dentro ad un nuovo più fu’ inretito
97 e dissi: «Già contento requïevi 98 di grande ammirazion; ma ora ammiro 99 com’ io trascenda questi corpi levi».
query.result:
**English:**
94 If I was relieved of my first doubt 95 by the brief, smiling words, 96 I was ensnared even more by a new one
97 and I said: "I was already content and at rest 98 from great wonder; but now I marvel 99 at how I transcend these light bodies".
**Old English:**
94 Gif ic wæs ðæs æroran twyn gefreodod 95 ðurh ða smilendan worda gesælda, 96 ða wæs ic eft on oðrum genearwod
97 and cwæð: "Ic wæs ær ðæs miclan wundres 98 genihtsum and gesælig; ac nu ic wundrige 99 hu ic ðas leohtan lichoman oferstíge".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Ond’ ella, appresso d’un pïo sospiro, 101 li occhi drizzò ver’ me con quel sembiante 102 che madre fa sovra figlio deliro,
103 e cominciò: «Le cose tutte quante 104 hanno ordine tra loro, e questo è forma 105 che l’universo a Dio fa simigliante.
query.result:
**English:**
100 And she, after a sigh, 101 turned her eyes toward me with that look 102 that a mother gives her delirious son,
103 and began: "All things have order among themselves, 104 and this is the form 105 that makes the universe resemble God.
**Old English:**
100 And heo, æfter anum sihoe, 101 hire eagan aræærde to me mid ðæm ansyne 102 ðe moder ðeð ofer hire deliran sunu,
103 and ðus cwæð: "Ealle ðing habbað endebyrdnysse betwynan him, 104 and ðis is ðæt hiw 105 ðe ðone ealldor Gode gelicneð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Qui veggion l’alte creature l’orma 107 de l’etterno valore, il qual è fine 108 al quale è fatta la toccata norma.
query.result:
**English:**
106 Here the high creatures see the imprint 107 of the eternal worth, which is the end 108 for which the created norm is made.
**Old English:**
106 Hēr ðā hēan gesceaft gesihð ðā lāst 107 ðæs ēcan weorðmynts, se is ende 108 ðǣm is geworht ðæt gesceaftlīce rīht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Vero è che, come forma non s’accorda 128 molte fïate a l’intenzion de l’arte, 129 perch’ a risponder la materia è sorda,
130 così da questo corso si diparte 131 talor la creatura, c’ha podere 132 di piegar, così pinta, in altra parte;
133 e sì come veder si può cadere 134 foco di nube, sì l’impeto primo 135 l’atterra torto da falso piacere.
query.result:
**English:**
127 It is true that, just as form does not always accord 128 with the intention of the artist, 129 because the material is resistant to being shaped,
130 so too the creature, who has the power 131 to bend, thus driven, in another direction, 132 sometimes departs from this course;
133 and just as one can see fire fall 134 from a cloud, so the initial impetus 135 knocks it down, twisted, by false pleasure.
**Old English:**
127 Soð is ðætte, swa swa hiw ne geþafað 128 oft ðære cræfte ðæs wyrhtan willan, 129 forðæm ðe ðæt efne bið unsweotol,
130 swa ðeos gesceaft hwilum gewiteð 131 fram ðissum ryne, ðe hæfð mihte 132 ðurh ðone onscyndan ðing on oðre healfe;
133 and swa swa man mæg geseon feallan 134 fyr of wolcne, swa ðæt forma anginn 135 ðurh ðone leasan lust ðæt astyreð to ðære eorðan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Non dei più ammirar, se bene stimo, 137 lo tuo salir, se non come d’un rivo 138 se d’alto monte scende giuso ad imo.
query.result:
**English:**
136 You should not marvel more, if I judge correctly, 137 at your ascent, except as at a river 138 that descends from a high mountain to the bottom.
**Old English:**
136 Ne ðu ðæs wundrige, gif ic wel deme, 137 ðines upstiges, buton swa ea wæteres, 138 ðe of dune síðe sígeð to grunde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Maraviglia sarebbe in te se, privo 140 d’impedimento, giù ti fossi assiso, 141 com’ a terra quïete in foco vivo».
query.result:
**English:**
139 It would be a marvel in you if, deprived 140 of impediment, you had sat down below, 141 as quiet on earth as a live coal in fire.
**Old English:**
139 Wundor bið ðe gif ðu, freoða leas, 140 ungebunden, niðer sittan miht, 141 swa ðu on eorðan fyr unbræcne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 Quinci rivolse inver’ lo cielo il viso.
query.result:
**English:**
142 Then he turned his face toward heaven.
**Old English:**
142 Þa he wende his neb ongen ðone heofon.
